title: Life Lessons from the Land: Why Traditional Farming Can Save Your Life (And Build Real Strength)

tasks.task: Digging a corner post for a temporary fence.
subtasks: Using a post hole digger.
Exerting physical force to dig into the ground.
Ensuring the post is secure for the fence.
Ensuring a stable post by solidly inserting it.
Planning the placement of electric fence to manage livestock movement.
Considering the edge effect for biodiversity.
Preparing the ground for planting oats.
Considering the timing and method of planting (e.g., direct seeding into dust instead of mud).
Rotational grazing management.
Planting wheat as a nurse crop under alfalfa.
Understanding the compatibility and benefits of alfalfa and wheat in rotation.
Understanding the impact of endophyte-infected fescue on animal health.
Rotational cropping systems to manage soil fertility.
Recognizing the volatility of geopolitical situations (e.g., high risk of nuclear conflict).
Considering self-sufficiency through diverse crop cultivation (e.g., oats for feeding animals/humans).

tasks.task: Exercising physical fitness through manual labor.
subtasks: Using farm tools like post hole diggers for strength building.
Engaging in activities that require physical exertion (arm, deltoid, and shoulder exercises).
Building resilience against societal norms that undervalue manual labor.
Constructing ponds and water features for livestock hydration.
Ensuring water quality and accessibility for animals.
